author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,346
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Feb. 24, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Russia Is Wooing Western Energy Companies, but Will They Return?
description: Industry experts say Western companies will need to weigh potential access to oil and gas riches against political risks and other hazards of doing business in Russia.
content: Kremlin officials are dangling the prospect of lucrative investment deals for American energy companies, apparently seeking to convince President Trump that large economic gains could come from siding with Moscow in ending the war in Ukraine and scrapping economic sanctions on Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Amid Regional Diplomatic Furor, Sudan’s Paramilitaries Forge a Rival Government
description: The Rapid Support Forces said it was paving the way to an end to the civil war. Critics called it an audacious gambit by a group that the United States has accused of genocide.
content: The Rapid Support Forces, the paramilitary group fighting Sudan’s military in the country’s calamitous civil war, signed a political charter with its allies late Saturday that aimed to establish a parallel Sudanese government in areas under their control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Screen Actors Guild Awards 2025: Date, Time and Streaming
description: In a wide-open best picture race, the awards, which are streaming on Netflix, could offer some clarity.
content: This year’s Oscars best picture race is, for the first time in years, wide open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Hegseth Defends Trump’s Firing of Joint Chiefs Chairman
description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said in an interview on Sunday that Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. was “not the right man for the moment” and praised President Trump’s handling of the war in Ukraine.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth on Sunday defended President Trump’s firing of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation’s top military officer, arguing that he was “not the right man for the moment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Republicans Face Angry Voters at Town Halls, Hinting at Broader Backlash
description: After a monthlong honeymoon for the G.O.P. at the start of President Trump’s term, lawmakers are confronting a groundswell of fear and disaffection in districts around the country.
content: Some came with complaints about Elon Musk, President Trump’s billionaire ally who is carrying out an assault on the federal bureaucracy. Others demanded guarantees that Republicans in Congress would not raid the social safety net. Still others chided the G.O.P. to push back against Mr. Trump’s moves to trample the constitutional power of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Fatima AbdulKarim
title: Hamas Frees 6 Hostages as Israel Delays Palestinian Prisoner Release
description: The six Israelis were the last living captives set to be released in the first phase of the cease-fire. The agreement, strained for weeks, has an uncertain future.
content: Hamas released six Israeli hostages from Gaza on Saturday, delivering the last living captives set to be freed in the first phase of a fragile cease-fire. That truce was already jolted this week when the militant group initially returned remains purportedly of an Israeli hostage that testing revealed to be someone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: For Fearful Immigrants, It’s the Card They All Want Right Now
description: Distributed by a legal aid group, the “red card” lays out key rights and protections. Demand for them has surged since President Trump returned to office.
content: It is the size of a credit card, comes in 19 languages and is in the pockets and purses of millions of immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: I Teach at Harvard. Store Managers See Me as a Threat.
description: Maybe I just wanted to be seen as something other than a threat, a nuisance, because I happen to be Black.
content: In November, two days before my 44th birthday, behind a local bike shop that I frequent, a manager from inside the shop approached me and mentioned something about the police. If I were still on probation, which I was for about three years ending in 2008, running my name might have triggered an arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Trump’s Frustration With Generals Resulted in an Unconventional Pick
description: Lt. Gen. Dan Caine, a retired three-star Air Force officer, quickly moved up the list of candidates to be the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
content: By late last week, President Trump had decided to fire Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and replace him with one of two very different candidates, according to two administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: At Least 3 Dead After Boat Capsizes Near Staten Island, Officials Say
description: Officials said one person was missing and two people were hospitalized after the boat, with six aboard, overturned on Sunday in the Ambrose Channel.
content: At least three people died and one person was still missing after a boat they were in capsized in the frigid waters of the Ambrose Channel near Staten Island on Sunday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: The Battle of Iwo Jima: A History
description: U.S. Marines raised an American flag on the Japanese island’s highest peak exactly 80 years ago. But the fighting, some of the deadliest of World War II, would rage on for a month.
content: Iwo Jima has always been beautiful, a volcanic chunk of rock surrounded by cobalt sea. But a World War II battle 80 years ago this month turned the Japanese island into a byword for desperate, deadly combat — and for American triumph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany’s Votes Are Cast. What Happens Now?
description: The country appears headed for a coalition government. But the process of building one could take months.
content: Now that the votes are cast, the real work in Berlin can begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Expanding West Bank Campaign, Israel Sends Tanks for First Time in Decades
description: Israel’s defense minister, Israel Katz, said that 40,000 Palestinian residents displaced from militant hotbeds would not be allowed to return to their homes.
content: Israel announced on Sunday that it was expanding its weekslong military operation against armed Palestinian groups in the occupied West Bank and had deployed tanks in the territory’s north for the first time in two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Spicy, Sparkling New Romance Novels
description: Our columnist on the month’s new releases.
content: Novels have always reflected technology. How we write fiction changed after the invention of photography, radio, film and email. This month we look at two romance novels that make a strong case for what we might call the Instagram or TikTok voice, as well as a historical that reminds us that the past is not as different a country as we might wish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ken Rosenthal, Founder of Panera Bread’s Forerunner, Dies at 81
description: He built a small chain of bakery cafes, with sourdough bread as its star. A few years after it was sold, it became nationally famous under a new name.
content: Ken Rosenthal, who opened a bakery cafe in the St. Louis area, with sourdough bread as its star, and built it into a small chain that would become Panera Bread, died on Feb. 14 at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Hamed Aleaziz
title: This Christian Convert Fled Iran, and Ran Into Trump’s Deportation Policy
description: Artemis Ghasemzadeh is among a group of migrants being held in a jungle camp in Panama.
content: She first entered a church on a visit to Turkey. She remembers feeling a sense of calm so overpowering that she purchased a small Bible. She wrapped it in her clothes and smuggled it back to her hometown, Isfahan, in central Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terry Parris Jr
title: What Project Is Changing Your Community?
description: Headway, a team at The New York Times that reports on progress and possibility, wants to hear about the efforts shaping your community. What’s working? What’s not? What should we look into?
content: At Headway, we report on big problems through the lens of progress. We’ve covered efforts to curb homelessness in Houston, understand what reduces gun violence in Baton Rouge and improve public transit in Bogotá, as well as many other subjects around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Shesol
title: John Roberts Is on a Collision Course With Trump
description: Besieged on all sides, the chief justice faces his greatest test yet.
content: Alexander Hamilton saw it coming. In the Federalist Papers, he described the judiciary as a feeble branch of government, easily “overpowered, awed or influenced” by Congress and the president. Lacking the means to enforce their rulings, judges, he wrote, would need an “uncommon portion of fortitude.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 624
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Feb. 24, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Swiss Peak
description: Rena Cohen offers a series of clarifications.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Federico Rios
title: No Exit
description: About 300 migrants from all around the world were deported from the United States to Panama. There, they were trapped in a hotel, facing a choice of whether to return to places they had fled.
content: In furtive messages, sent through handmade signs, hidden phones and gestures behind glass, some of the migrants expressed a sense of constant, overwhelming fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: ‘Religious Motivation’ Possible in Berlin Stabbing, Police Say
description: The suspect, a Syrian refugee, told the police that a plan had come into his mind to kill Jews. The attack raises tensions just before an election in which immigration is a big issue.
content: The man detained in connection with the stabbing of a Spanish tourist at Berlin’s Holocaust memorial on Friday may have been planning for weeks to kill Jewish people, according to German authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Maggie Haberman
title: Some Trump Appointees Resist Musk’s Ultimatum to Federal Workers
description: The F.B.I. director, Kash Patel, the director of national intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, and others told employees not to respond to a directive from Mr. Musk to summarize their accomplishments.
content: Several Trump-appointed agency leaders urged federal workers not to comply with Elon Musk’s order to summarize their accomplishments for the past week or be removed from their positions, even as Mr. Musk doubled down on his demand over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Euan Ward
title: Hezbollah Stages Show of Strength at Funeral for Assassinated Leader
description: The Iran-backed Lebanese militant group held an elaborate commemoration for its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, who was killed by Israel in September.
content: Hezbollah put on a show of strength on Sunday with an elaborate and sprawling funeral for its assassinated leader, Hassan Nasrallah, an event the Iran-backed militant group hopes will revive its battered image in Lebanon after the latest war with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
title: Here are the latest developments.
description: Germans voted for a change of leadership on Sunday, with historically reliable exit polls from a parliamentary election showing centrist conservatives in the lead and the far right in second. The results amounted to a rebuke of the nation’s left-leaning government for its handling of the economy and immigration.
content: Germans voted for a change of leadership on Sunday, with historically reliable exit polls from a parliamentary election showing centrist conservatives in the lead and the far right in second. The results amounted to a rebuke of the nation’s left-leaning government for its handling of the economy and immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Forman Jr., Prentice Onayemi, Adrienne Hurst, Krish Seenivasan, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Catherine Anderson and Brian St. Pierre
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What Happened When America Emptied Its Youth Prisons’
description: Lessons from a radical 20-year experiment and a quiet triumph of public policy.
content: When David Muhammad was 15, his mother moved from Oakland, Calif., to Philadelphia with her boyfriend, leaving Muhammad in the care of his brothers, ages 20 and 21, both of whom were involved in the drug scene. Over the next two years, Muhammad was arrested three times — for selling drugs, attempted murder and illegal gun possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Review: ‘Suits LA’ Is Flat and Joyless
description: This NBC attempt to capitalize on the surprising Netflix success of “Suits” has almost none of the charms that distinguished the original.
content: “Suits LA” is a spinoff of “Suits” — a sequel, sort of, but it feels like a seance. Gather, viewers, as we attempt to contact the spirit of “Suits.” Can you feel it in the room with us? Its fraternal jockeying? Its fascination with sleeveless tops as office wear for women? Maybe looking at a photograph of one of its characters will help maintain the delusion. Maybe hearing the theme song. Ooooohh. “Suits” says hi. “Suits” misses you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: Earth’s 1st Asteroid Mining Prospector Heads to the Launchpad
description: The dream of mining metals in deep space crashed and burned in the 2010s. AstroForge’s Odin mission to survey a potentially metallic asteroid is packed and ready to lift off.
content: A private company is aiming to heave a microwave oven-size spacecraft toward an asteroid later this week, its goal to kick off a future where precious metals are mined around the solar system to create vast fortunes on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Austria, a Longtime Buyer of Russian Gas, Tries to Break the Habit
description: OMV, a multinational energy company based in Vienna, has shifted to other options, including increasing its own output of natural gas, drilling for oil and experimenting with geothermal energy.
content: Just a few minutes’ walk from a metro station in the northeast corner of Vienna, you might think that you were in Texas: A drilling rig more than 130 feet high looms over open land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: SAG Awards Photos: See the Looks From the 2025 Red Carpet
description: Check out what film and television stars wore as they arrived for the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday night.
content: In a season that has many award shows, the Screen Actors Guild ceremony does something few others can: It focuses strictly on the stars. (Those who work behind the scenes will get their due next weekend.) On Sunday night, at the 31st SAG Awards, television and film actors were celebrated, as individuals and as ensembles. Winners were handed a statuette depicting a nude male figure; many remarked on its heft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Friedrich Merz, a Conservative, Is Poised to Be Germany’s Next Chancellor
description: The Christian Democrat, who appeared to have a path to a stable governing coalition, hopes to lead Europe’s response to President Trump’s reshuffling of alliances.
content: Germans voted for a change of leadership on Sunday, handing the most votes in a parliamentary election to centrist conservatives, with the far right in second, and rebuking the nation’s left-leaning government for its handling of the economy and immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Suffering From Kidney Failure in Addition to Pneumonia
description: The kidney ailment appears to be in an early stage, the Vatican said, adding that the pontiff is still receiving high flows of oxygen for his respiratory illness.
content: Pope Francis is suffering from “initial, mild kidney failure” in addition to the serious respiratory illness that has left the 88-year-old pontiff in critical condition in a Rome hospital, the Vatican said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Turned to See a Woman in Running Gear Walking Toward an Older Man’
description: Stooping to help on a Manhattan sidewalk, an A train dance party and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing: Conservatives Near Victory in Germany
description: Plus, a pharaoh’s tomb was unearthed.
content: The conservative Christian Democrats appeared to be on the cusp of victory in Germany’s parliamentary elections yesterday, exit polls show. The country’s next chancellor will almost certainly be Friedrich Merz, a businessman who has promised to crack down on migrants, and slash taxes and business regulations in a bid to kick-start economic growth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 23, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 23, 2025.
content: An article this weekend on Page 28 about the actor Jack Quaid misstates the surname of the actress who plays Mr. Quaid’s love interest on “The Boys.” It is Erin Moriarty, not Morgenstern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Firewall? Why the Far Right Is Unlikely to Join Germany’s Next Government
description: The collective shunning of the AfD party is part of a longstanding attempt to blunt its move into the mainstream.
content: Germany’s next government will almost certainly be a coalition of multiple political parties, to form a majority in Parliament. But one party will almost certainly be excluded from that coalition, no matter how well it ultimately performs: the hard-right Alternative for Germany, or AfD.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Running Point,’ Plus 5 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Kate Hudson stars as a basketball team executive in a new comedy on Netflix, and the Oscars air on Sunday night.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, Feb. 24-March 2. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Shakes Sold to Nursing Homes Recalled After Deadly Listeria Outbreak
description: The frozen supplemental drinks have been linked to an outbreak of listeria that has killed at least 11 people and hospitalized 37.
content: Frozen shakes sold to nursing homes, hospitals and other institutions have been recalled after the drinks were tied to a yearslong deadly listeria outbreak, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: In Britain, a Fight Over a Film Studio Becomes a Test for the Economy
description: The national government has intervened in a local planning squabble, which has become a symbol for how far it will go to use development as a way to revive the British economy.
content: Andrew Rackstraw has lived in Marlow, a small, wealthy town on the River Thames about 30 miles west of London, for nearly three decades. Its main streets are dotted with luxury boutiques, high-end cafes and stores like Saddle Safari, Mr. Rackstraw’s bike shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Chris Murphy Emerges as a Clear Voice for Democrats Countering Trump
description: The third-term senator from Connecticut is eschewing caution and throwing out the traditional political playbook as he seeks a broader audience for his critiques of the president and his agenda.
content: As Senator Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, sat seething in his office last month watching President Trump blame diversity requirements at the Federal Aviation Administration for the deadly plane crash over the Potomac River, members of his staff warned him against publicly venting his rage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump Appointees Fire Hundreds at U.S.A.I.D. Working on Urgent Aid
description: The firings added to doubts about whether Secretary of State Marco Rubio, the agency’s acting head, supports lifesaving humanitarian assistance, as he has said he does.
content: Trump administration appointees running the main United States aid agency have in recent days fired hundreds of employees who help manage responses to urgent humanitarian crises around the world, according to two U.S. officials and four recent employees of the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel and Hamas Trade Accusations of Violating Fragile Cease-Fire
description: Hamas criticized Israel’s decision to delay the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, amid growing tensions and concerns for the future of the truce in Gaza.
content: Israel and Hamas on Sunday accused each other of violating the already fragile Gaza cease-fire deal after Israel delayed the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners who were supposed to be exchanged for hostages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Macron and Starmer Have Played Trump’s Game Before, but the Rules Are Changing
description: The leaders of France and Britain are both due to meet with President Trump this week. Approaches previously tried with him may no longer work.
content: When the leaders of France and Britain meet President Trump at the White House this week, they can draw on a well-worn playbook for dealing with their mercurial host. But it is not clear that the old tricks will be enough to meet the new challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Nayeri
title: America Loses Its Soul When It Rejects People Fleeing Danger
description: A civilized society protects the world’s most vulnerable.
content: I’ve been thinking a lot lately about what it means to be “civilized.” It’s not caring for one’s own; animals do that. It’s not making music and art; cave men drew and sang. It is, I believe, to live with a moral standard that takes into account our fellow man, and to ask: What do we owe one another, and what do we owe strangers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Meet the Man Who Is Poised to Lead Germany
description: Friedrich Merz, head of the conservative Christian Democrats, has vowed to bring stronger leadership to Europe, where the new Trump administration has sowed anxiety.
content: Friedrich Merz, the man who is almost certain to be Germany’s next chancellor, is a conservative businessman who has never been a minister and was forced out of government years ago in a power struggle with Angela Merkel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Trump Has One Idea
description: What do Ukraine and the Justice Department have in common?
content: I grew up a Reagan Republican in the middle of the Cold War, and I never thought I’d see the day when the president of the United States became the world’s most prominent and effective Russian propagandist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner Nunn
title: The Teacher in Room 1214
description: When a gunman killed two of her students, Ivy Schamis was the only adult in the room. Her journey through guilt and healing sheds light on the impossible role of American teachers.
content: It was 45 seconds too late, but the teacher had a plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Got Ground Meat? Cook Some Keema.
description: Tejal Rao’s keema is simple and comforting, perfect for a Sunday night.
content: Good morning. There’s no better weekend morning than one that begins in line at Trinciti Roti Shop in Ozone Park, Queens, waiting amid the good-natured crowd for doubles to eat in the car afterward: one goat and one oxtail for now, with all the sauces, a bake and saltfish for later and, to wash it all down, a bottle of Peardrax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Trump Appointees Fire 2,000 U.S.A.I.D. Employees and Put Others Worldwide on Leave
description: The announcement, by email, came two days after a judge said the Trump administration could proceed with plans that amount to dismantling the aid agency.
content: Trump administration appointees in charge of the U.S. Agency for International Development sent employees an email on Sunday afternoon saying that they were firing 2,000 workers and putting up to thousands of foreign service officers and other direct hires around the world on paid leave starting that night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: These Books Are Absolutely Unreadable. That’s the Point.
description: A new exhibition at the Center for Book Arts in New York features a range of items — transistor radios, lanterns, cigarette lighters and more — designed to look like books.
content: A benign quirk of humanity is that we are delighted by things designed to look like other things. A bed shaped like a swan. A sauna shaped like a garlic bulb. A toilet brush shaped like a cherry. The designer Elsa Schiaparelli made fashion history with her acts of surreal mimicry, creating buttons in the form of crickets, a compact that looks like a rotary phone dial, a belt buckle of manicured hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Feintzeig
title: Why You, Too, Need a Nemesis
description: Many successful people understand the power of a grudge — athletes, pop stars, your mother-in-law, our president.
content: You’ve tried shadow journaling, manifesting and microdosing. But to really succeed in life, have you considered getting a nemesis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulette Perhach
title: Debt Nearly Buried Them. Here’s How They Got Out of the Hole.
description: People who find themselves in financial trouble sometimes consider taking drastic measures when their situation appears hopeless. But there is always a way out.
content: Decades ago, John Glover, a lawyer then in his early 30s with a wife and two children, found himself standing in a bank lobby trying to figure out how he could stretch what little remained in his account to cover his expenses. Foreclosure loomed. He wanted to float a check, write it and worry about having the money in the account later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Artem Chekh and Iva Sidash
title: This Is Our Country, and We Have No Other
description: How long can Ukraine stand? For as long as Ukrainian soldiers, bent over from the extreme pressure, can hold on.
content: Most people would not be eager to go to war. Such a desire is often related to some youthful romanticism or, in some cases, a kind of mental disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Censoring Games
description: What China’s influence over Marvel Rivals reveals about censorship.
content: Marvel Rivals is one of the biggest video games in the world. Since its launch in December, more than 40 million people have signed up to fight one another as comic book heroes like Iron Man and Wolverine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Michael Wines
title: The Death of Competition in American Elections
description: A vast majority of 2024 races for Congress and state legislatures were decided by low-turnout or meaningless primaries. The trend is making politics more polarized and eroding public trust.
content: President Trump’s return to Washington has tested the bounds of presidential power and set off alarms among Democrats, historians and legal scholars who are warning that the country’s democratic order is under threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Camille Elemia
title: Catholics Pray for Ailing Pope Francis at Sunday Mass
description: The 88-year-old pontiff, who has been hospitalized for more than a week, had a restful night after receiving oxygen and a blood transfusion on Saturday, the Vatican said.
content: Roman Catholics worldwide prayed on Sunday for Pope Francis, who is hospitalized in critical condition, after the Vatican announced that he was “not out of danger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Trump’s Alternate Reality, Lies and Distortions Drive Change
description: Condoms for Gaza? Ukraine started the war with Russia? The president’s manipulations of the truth lay the groundwork for radical change.
content: The United States sent $50 million in condoms to Hamas. Diversity programs caused a plane crash. China controls the Panama Canal. Ukraine started the war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: An N.Y.C. Panel Is Tackling the Housing Crisis. Here’s How You Can Help.
description: The Charter Revision Commission, created by Mayor Eric Adams, could give New Yorkers a rare chance to decide how the city deals with the housing crisis.
content: Most New Yorkers probably have not read the City Charter, which outlines the workings of city government and is often compared to the U.S. Constitution. But this year, a panel of civic leaders will suggest revisions that could help relieve the housing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Joy Reid’s MSNBC Show Canceled in Major Shake-Up
description: Ms. Reid’s 7 p.m. program will be replaced by a panel show co-hosted by Symone Sanders Townsend, Alicia Menendez and Michael Steele.
content: Joy Reid’s evening news show on MSNBC is being canceled, part of a far-reaching programming overhaul orchestrated by Rebecca Kutler, the network’s new president, two people familiar with the changes said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: French Doctor Already Convicted of Child Sex Abuse Faces Hundreds More Charges
description: Dr. Joël Le Scouarnec is accused of raping or sexually assaulting 299 people, mostly his patients, mostly children, over 25 years, in the country’s largest-ever pedophilia case.
content: Dr. Joël Le Scouarnec was a veteran surgeon when the police burst into his home in 2017 searching for evidence after a girl who lived next door accused him of exposing himself to her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Memory of Our Decency: ‘That Was U.S.A.I.D.’
description: Reflections on the dismantling of the aid agency. Also: Birthright citizenship and the 14th Amendment; transgender policies; eagerness to march again.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Odom and Sam Gurwitt
title: Voters Took Note of U.S. Meddling in Campaign
description: Several voters took note of a speech by Vice President JD Vance this month, when he told European leaders to stop shunning parties deemed “extreme.”
content: Interference by Trump administration officials in the German campaign put off some left-leaning voters but was welcomed by others supporting the far-right Alternative for Germany, or AfD, according to a smattering of interviews at polling stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephin Merritt
title: A Not-So-Straight Line From Little Richard to Bowie to ‘Saturday Night Fever’
description: In “The Secret Public,” Jon Savage traces how music helped popularize queer culture, from the 1950s through the heyday of disco.
content: Jon Savage, the author of the epic punk history “England’s Dreaming,” returns with an even longer examination of the dual histories of pop music and gay life, from the beginning of the rock era in 1955 to the fall of disco in 1979, ending just before MTV and AIDS. His intention in “The Secret Public” is to show how gay musicians and audiences affected the mainstream, but too often the connections are left implied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germans Are Voting. Here’s What to Watch For.
description: What Germans decide in national elections that are likely to produce a new chancellor will be of critical importance as Europe re-evaluates relations with the Trump administration.
content: Germans are voting on Sunday in a rare snap election that has taken on outsize importance as the new Trump administration threatens European countries with tariffs, cuts them out of negotiations over Ukraine and embraces an authoritarian Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Ana Ley
title: They Help Make the Hamptons the Hamptons, and Now They’re Living in Fear
description: Latino immigrants care for some of America’s most lavish beachside mansions. Their disappearance would affect the wealthy, too.
content: The party dresses must be double-pressed, the hedges shaved into sharp rectangles. The hand soap and lotion dispensers must be formed into neat lines along bathroom sinks. Caterers need to slip out of view as soon as the oysters and cocktails are served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky Pushes Back Against U.S. Mineral Deal and Announces European Summit
description: The Ukrainian leader also said he would step down if Ukraine was allowed to join NATO, though it was unclear if he was serious or not.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed back on Sunday against demands from the Trump administration for billions in Ukrainian natural resources and for holding peace talks that exclude Ukraine, while announcing plans for a major summit of European leaders on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan, Laura Bult, Melanie Bencosme and Harvey Glen
title: The Red Card Fighting Trump’s Deportation Agenda
description: The “red card” lists practical tips and legal rights for immigrants who might find themselves targeted by federal agents. It has received nine million orders since Donald Trump was elected. Miriam Jordan, a national immigration correspondent for The New York Times, describes this “extraordinary moment” of anxiety for immigrants and what the card has meant to immigrants, rights groups and the Trump administration.
content: The “red card” lists practical tips and legal rights for immigrants who might find themselves targeted by federal agents. It has received nine million orders since Donald Trump was elected. Miriam Jordan, a national immigration correspondent for The New York Times, describes this “extraordinary moment” of anxiety for immigrants and what the card has meant to immigrants, rights groups and the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Tens of Thousands Mourn Hezbollah’s Former Leader
description: Hezbollah supporters gathered to pay tribute to Hassan Nasrallah, the group’s former leader, and Hashem Safieddine, another top official, at a funeral service held months after both were killed by Israel.
content: Hezbollah supporters gathered to pay tribute to Hassan Nasrallah, the group’s former leader, and Hashem Safieddine, another top official, at a funeral service held months after both were killed by Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Israel and Hamas Accuse Each Other of Violating Cease-Fire Deal
description: Israel delayed the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners until Hamas assured the release of more hostages.
content: Israel delayed the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners until Hamas assured the release of more hostages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg, Doug Mills, Rebecca Suner, Laura Bult, Laura Salaberry and Pierre Kattar
title: What We Know About Guantánamo Bay’s Migrant Camp
description: Last month, President Trump announced plans to construct a migrant holding facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Carol Rosenberg breaks down what we know about the operation, along with New York Times photographer Doug Mills, who captured the first independent images of the facility.
content: Last month, President Trump announced plans to construct a migrant holding facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Carol Rosenberg breaks down what we know about the operation, along with New York Times photographer Doug Mills, who captured the first independent images of the facility.
source.name: The New York Times
